courseTitle: Biological Macromolecules for Anatomy and Physiology

pageData.titleName2: Biological Macromolecules for Anatomy and Physiology

pageData.text: All living organisms are composed of organic molecules that can be divided into four classes: <button class='glossary-text'>carbohydrates</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>proteins</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>lipids</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>nucleic acids</button>. Students will use molecular models to explore the chemistry of these groups and gain an understanding of how complex molecules are built from simpler ones.

pageData.title: Time required
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Carbohydrates - 45 minutes
Activity 2: Proteins - 45 minutes
Activity 3: Lipids - 45 minutes
Activity 4: Nucleic Acids - 45 minutes
pageData.desc:

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Use chemical formulas and drawings to construct molecular models of organic molecules.
Recognize functional groups common to organic molecules and identify them in drawings and the molecular models constructed.
Demonstrate and explain dehydration synthesis and <button class='glossary-text'>hydrolysis</button> reactions.

pageData.text: It seems like every year new “fad diets” are advertised. In 1918, the first U.S. fad diet book was published by Lulu Hunt Peters, “Diet & Health: With Key to the Calories”. She suggested that it didn’t matter what a person ate, as long as they only consumed the number of calories that was appropriate for their height. And if the recommended calorie amount was followed, then a person could lose weight. However, it is now understood that eating a balanced diet and maintaining an active lifestyle is an integral part of weight loss.Eating a balanced diet is important and provides the nutrients that your body needs to function effectively. A balanced diet strengthens the immune system and helps protect against communicable and chronic non-communicable diseases. Recently, the USDA introduced the food plate, modified from the food pyramid, to help people remember that everyone needs a balance of fruits, vegetables, grains, , and smaller amounts of oils and dairy products. Rather than following a strict “diet” they recommend that everyone consume a variety of grains, fruits, and vegetables and limit the amount of saturated fat, sugar, and salt.

pageData.altText: The USDA food plate diagram from myplate.gov.

pageData.text: are the fundamental building blocks of matter, making up the 118 currently known elements. Atoms consist of three major particles: , , and . Protons and neutrons are located in the nucleus of the atom, whereas electrons are located in shells surrounding the nucleus. Each shell can hold a maximum number of electrons. For example, two electrons are found in the in the first shell, and eight electrons in the second. Atoms are most stable when their outer, or valence, shell is full. Atoms form with other atoms to achieve the lowest energy (most stable) state, thus creating molecules and compounds.Chemical bonds are electrons shared between two atoms. If the atoms are different, the attraction to these shared electrons will also be different. Chemical bonds are classified as covalent or ionic. Electrons are shared equally in nonpolar , unequally in polar covalent bonds, and fully transferred to the more electronegative atom in .The tendency for atoms to bond ionically or covalently is determined by the difference in their .

Electronegativity is a dimensionless value that is a measure of an atom’s ability to attract bonding valence electrons. Figure 1 shows the electronegativity of atoms commonly found in organic molecules. In the figure, the size of the atom indicates its relative molecular weight.

pageData.desc: Figure 1. Relative molecular weight and electronegativity of atoms commonly found in organic molecules
pageData.altText: Figure 1. Relative molecular weight and electronegativity of atoms commonly found in organic molecules

pageData.text: Nonpolar Covalent: If the difference in electronegativity of two atoms is small, the electrons are shared equally between the two atoms and the bond is a nonpolar covalent bond. Some examples of molecules with nonpolar covalent bonds are Cl2, H2, CH4, and CS2.

Polar Covalent: When the difference in electronegativity of two atoms is high, there is an unequal sharing of the electrons between the two atoms. Although all electrons are constantly moving within the (the region between the two atoms where the shared electrons are most likely to be found), in polar covalent bonds the electrons are more attracted to the atom with higher electronegativity and will spend more time closer to that atom. This unequal sharing creates poles of charges; thus, these bonds are termed polar covalent bonds. Some examples of molecules with polar covalent bonds are NH3 and H2O.

pageData.question: Which of the following molecules is most likely to be non-polar?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The electronegativity difference between two nitrogen atoms is zero, so the electrons of this molecule are shared equally between the atoms and the bond is nonpolar covalent.

pageData.question: Oxygen has an electronegativity value of 3.44; hydrogen has an electronegativity value of 2.2. Atoms of these elements can combine to form water molecules (H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O). Which of the following best describes the electron distribution in a molecule of water?

options.text: The oxygen atom sees more electrons than the hydrogen atoms.
The hydrogen atoms each see more electrons than the oxygen atom.
One hydrogen atom sees more electrons than the other two atoms.
The electrons are shared equally between the oxygen atom and each hydrogen atom.
The electrons from the oxygen atom are completely transferred to the hydrogen atoms.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In polar covalent bonds the electrons are more attracted to the atom with higher electronegativity and will spend more time closer to that atom. Oxygen has a higher electronegativity than hydrogen, so the electrons in a water molecule spend more time near the oxygen atom.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Nonpolar covalent bonds form between atoms where the electronegativity difference between them is small or zero. When the electronegativity difference is small, the electrons of the bonded atoms are shared equally and no poles form in the molecule. Diatomic molecules, such as the gases Cl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> and H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>, are nonpolar because the electronegativity difference between the atoms is zero. Other molecules, such as CH<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub> and CS<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>, are also nonpolar because they have small electronegativity differences. Polar covalent bonds form between atoms with large electronegativity differences. The electrons in these bonds are shared unevenly, creating poles in the molecule. The atom with the larger electronegativity will see the electrons in the bond more often than the atom with the smaller electronegativity.

img.alt: Figure 1. Relative molecular weight and electronegativity of atoms commonly found in organic molecules

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Nonpolar covalent bonds form between atoms where the electronegativity difference between them is small or zero. When the electronegativity difference is small, the electrons of the bonded atoms are shared equally and no poles form in the molecule. Diatomic molecules, such as the gases Cl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> and H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>, are nonpolar because the electronegativity difference between the atoms is zero. Other molecules, such as CH<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub> and CS<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>, are also nonpolar because they have small electronegativity differences. Polar covalent bonds form between atoms with large electronegativity differences. The electrons in these bonds are shared unevenly, creating poles in the molecule. The atom with the larger electronegativity will see the electrons in the bond more often than the atom with the smaller electronegativity.

img.alt: Figure 1. Relative molecular weight and electronegativity of atoms commonly found in organic molecules

pageData.text: Ionic: This type of bond occurs when there is complete transfer of the between the two . This occurs when the difference in is >1.8. NaCl and MgCl2 are typical examples.A third type of “bond,” a , is a special type of electrical attraction between polar molecules. Hydrogen bonds can lead to attractions between molecules, such as water, or between polar regions of large molecules, such as and DNA. Hydrogen bonds are much weaker than ionic or and can be disrupted by increases in temperature, salt concentration, and the presence of detergents; however, they are very important in the body. is the study of compounds of carbon and hydrogen. Carbon contains four electrons in its valence shell and, thus, will form four covalent bonds with other atoms to achieve stability. Most important organic molecules in the body consist of chains or rings of carbon with attached functional groups. It is these functional groups that participate in chemical reactions. Biological molecules can be divided into four distinct types based on chemical properties and structure: , proteins, , and .

Three of these classes (carbohydrates, proteins, and nucleic acids) are composed of discrete units <button class='glossary-text'>(monomers)</button>: that can be linked <button class='glossary-text'>(polymerized)</button> to form more complex structures <button class='glossary-text'>(polymers)</button>. The chemical reaction that causes bonds to be formed between monomers is called dehydration synthesis. The breaking of bonds within a polymer by chemical reaction with water to remove a monomer is called <button class='glossary-text'>hydrolysis</button>.

pageData.question: Organic chemistry is the study of compounds with what atomic elements?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Organic chemistry is the study of compounds of carbon and hydrogen.

pageData.question: Organic molecules are stable molecules made up largely of carbon. Which of the following best describes the property of carbon that provides this stability?

options.text: Carbon can form four covalent bonds.
Carbon has a high electronegativity value.
Carbon can form double and triple bonds.
Carbon can only bond to hydrogen atoms.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Carbon contains four electrons in its valence shell and will form four covalent bonds with other atoms to achieve stability. This allows carbon-rich organic molecules to form stable chain or ring structures.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Organic molecules are stable because they are made up of carbon, which contains four electrons in its valence shell and, thus, will form four covalent bonds with other atoms to achieve stability. The most prevalent of these other atoms that bond to carbon in organic molecules is hydrogen. Most important organic molecules are chains or rings of carbon with attached functional groups featuring other atomic elements. It is the functional groups that participate in chemical reactions because they are less stable than the main carbon-hydrogen structure.

img.alt: The chemical structure of benzene. It is ring-shaped, made up of six carbon atoms and six hydrogen atoms. Every other bond between the carbon atoms in the ring is a double bond.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Organic molecules are stable because they are made up of carbon, which contains four electrons in its valence shell and, thus, will form four covalent bonds with other atoms to achieve stability. The most prevalent of these other atoms that bond to carbon in organic molecules is hydrogen. Most important organic molecules are chains or rings of carbon with attached functional groups featuring other atomic elements. It is the functional groups that participate in chemical reactions because they are less stable than the main carbon-hydrogen structure.

img.alt: The chemical structure of benzene. It is ring-shaped, made up of six carbon atoms and six hydrogen atoms. Every other bond between the carbon atoms in the ring is a double bond.

pageData.text: In this lab, you will be constructing models of a variety of different types of organic molecules. In each molecule, you will identify the important functional groups. Finally, you will demonstrate the chemical combination of to form through the process of dehydration, as well as the breakdown of larger molecules by ., , , and have chemically reactive sites called functional groups. Functional groups contain a recognizable subset of within a larger molecule and are responsible for characteristic chemical reactions. The five functional groups that are commonly found in carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids are listed in Table 1.

pageData.title: Table 1.
header: Compounds in Which Functional Group Occurs
Compounds in Which Functional Group Occurs

pageData.text:
Carbohydrates
Carbohydrates are one class of biological molecules made up of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. The basic units of carbohydrates are sugars, which consist of a chain or ring of carbon atoms with hydrogen and hydroxyl groups. A subgroup of sugars is characterized by the aldehyde functional group. Examples of sugars are glucose, maltose, and ribose. Sugars are the first stable product of photosynthesis, and the preferred substrate for respiration. In order to condense molecules and minimize storage space, organisms will link multiple sugars together to form complex carbohydrates or . Polysaccharides may contain thousands of joined by . Examples of complex carbohydrates are starch, cellulose, and glycogen. All of these substances are used in cells as intermediate energy-storage compounds. Plant cells primarily store sugars as starch, whereas animal and fungal cells usually store sugars as glycogen.

In addition to their roles in energy storage, cellulose and glycogen are both used as structural molecules within cells. The cell walls of plants are made up of cellulose. The long, unbranched chains of sugars are aligned in parallel rows that are held together by <button class='glossary-text'>hydrogen bonds</button>. This structure makes the cell wall resistant to <button class='glossary-text'>hydrolysis</button> and, therefore, largely indigestible by humans. It nevertheless is an important component of the human diet, making up a large component of the fiber that is required to keep material moving efficiently through the digestive tract. Starch and glycogen, in contrast, are highly branched molecules, facilitating hydrolysis and rendering the molecules correspondingly easier to digest.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>In the liver, the primary function of glycogen is to store excess glucose from the blood and keep glucose levels down. When blood glucose levels fall, glycogen is broken down into glucose to maintain appropriate blood sugar levels. In muscle cells, the other major repository of glycogen in animal tissues, glycogen serves as a reserve energy source.

pageData.question: Which of the following is one function of carbohydrates in living organisms?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Carbohydrates can form complex polymers for storing thousands of monosaccharides, the preferred substrate for cellular respiration which provides cells with energy.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the structure of complex carbohydrates such as glycogen, an energy-storage molecule produced by animals?

options.text: many simple sugar molecules linked together
two simple sugar molecules linked together
many simple sugar molecules surrounded by a membrane

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Complex carbohydrates, or polysaccharides, are made up of many simple sugar molecules, or monosaccharides, linked together in long chains or branched structures.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Carbohydrates consist of sugar molecules, such as glucose, as their basic unit. They are produced by photosynthesis in plants and are the preferred substrate for cellular respiration in living organisms. Because sugar molecules are the preferred source of energy, organisms evolved biochemical pathways for linking multiple sugars together to form complex carbohydrates, which store sugar molecules more compactly until they are ready to be used. In organisms that lack internal skeletal systems (such as plants, fungi and insects) complex carbohydrates also serve as structural molecules, providing rigidity to cell walls or exoskeletons, and therefore overall structural support to these groups of organisms.

img.alt: An example of a cellulose molecule consisting of four ring-shaped sugar molecules linked together in a chain by glycosidic bonds.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Carbohydrates consist of sugar molecules, such as glucose, as their basic unit. They are produced by photosynthesis in plants and are the preferred substrate for cellular respiration in living organisms. Because sugar molecules are the preferred source of energy, organisms evolved biochemical pathways for linking multiple sugars together to form complex carbohydrates, which store sugar molecules more compactly until they are ready to be used. In organisms that lack internal skeletal systems (such as plants, fungi and insects) complex carbohydrates also serve as structural molecules, providing rigidity to cell walls or exoskeletons, and therefore overall structural support to these groups of organisms.

img.alt: An example of a cellulose molecule consisting of four ring-shaped sugar molecules linked together in a chain by glycosidic bonds.

pageData.text: The building blocks from which <button class='glossary-text'>proteins</button> and polypeptides are made are amino acids. Amino acids vary widely in size, structure, and characteristics, but they all have one structure in common. All amino acids have a basic structure consisting of a carboxyl group (–COOH) and an amino group (–NH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>) attached to a central carbon <button class='glossary-text'>atom</button>, as shown in Figure 2.

pageData.desc: Figure 2. Basic structure of an amino acid
pageData.altText: Figure 2. Basic structure of an amino acid

pageData.text: Amino acids differ from one another at the R group, a side chain that is attached to the central carbon. The R group varies in structure from a single hydrogen atom to a long carbon chain.

Two amino acids are joined by a dehydration reaction, in which a hydrogen atom is removed from an amino group on one molecule, and a hydroxyl group (–OH) is removed from the carboxyl end of the other molecule to form water (H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O) as shown in Figure 3. This reaction results in the formation of a <button class='glossary-text'>peptide bond</button>, which joins two amino acids to form a dipeptide.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>Multiple peptide units can be linked to form longer peptide chains called polypeptides. A protein consists of one or more polypeptide chains, which are folded and coiled into a specific shape.

pageData.desc: Figure 3. Two amino acids positioned for peptide bond formation
pageData.altText: Figure 3. Two amino acids positioned for peptide bond formation

pageData.text: Understanding proteins is crucial to understanding the processes of life. The amino acid sequence, the <button class='glossary-text'>primary structure</button>, is only the beginning of the complexity of proteins. Some R groups are hydrophobic, whereas other R groups have various degrees of polarity, causing <button class='glossary-text'>hydrogen bonds</button> to form between regions of opposing charge. Formation of these hydrogen bonds induces the protein to take on its <button class='glossary-text'>secondary structure</button>.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak><button class='glossary-text'>Secondary structures</button> include the α-helix and the β-pleated sheet. Other chemical interactions can take place between the side groups such as formation of salt bridges, which are <button class='glossary-text'>ionic bonds</button>. The regions formed by these specific interactions can participate in nonspecific interactions, such as the burial of hydrophobic regions in the interior of the <button class='glossary-text'>protein</button>. The folding of the secondary structural elements into specific domains generates the <button class='glossary-text'>tertiary structure</button>. The <button class='glossary-text'>quaternary structure</button> of a protein refers to that formed by the association of more than one peptide chain. This sequence of events induces the protein to fold into a distinct shape that is critical to the function that it performs.

Functions of proteins range from structural, such as those that form the cytoskeleton of cells and tissues such as cartilage and bone, to catalytic, as for enzymes, which accelerate chemical reactions. Because the shape of a protein determines its function, and because the shape of a protein is dependent on hydrogen bonding, any condition that disrupts <button class='glossary-text'>hydrogen bonds</button> can also disrupt protein function.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>Some amino acids, such as glycine, can be synthesized by the human body to meet the body’s needs; these are the <button class='glossary-text'>nonessential amino acids</button>. Nine amino acids, however, cannot be synthesized by the human body and must be supplied in a diet. These are the <button class='glossary-text'>essential amino acids</button> phenylalanine, valine, threonine, tryptophan, methionine, leucine, isoleucine, lysine, and histidine.

pageData.subTitle: Video: Primary, Secondary and Tertiary Structure

pageData.question: Which of the following components of an amino acid is variable in structure and defines the overall chemical properties of a particular amino acid?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: All amino acids have an amino group and a carboxyl group, both of which are attached to a central carbon. All amino acids also have an R group, which differs in structure for each type of amino acid.

pageData.question: Proteins perform a variety of functions in living organisms, such as providing structure or catalyzing chemical reactions. Which of the following properties of a protein is most critical to the function it performs?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Proteins are comprised of up to four levels of structure, all of which define their three-dimensional shape. It is the shape of each protein that allows it to perform a specific function. Environmental conditions that affect the way a protein is folded, and therefore its shape, can affect the function of that protein.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The monomer that makes up proteins and polypeptides is an amino acid. Each amino acid is made up of the same components – a carboxyl group, an amino group, and an R group, all attached to a central carbon atom as shown in Figure 2. Despite the similarity in their structure, there are twenty different types of amino acids. The differences between amino acids are found in the structure of their R groups. Some R groups consist of a single hydrogen atom while others are made up of carbon chains or rings. These unique structures are also responsible for differences in hydrophobicity, polarity, and other chemical properties between amino acids. It is these properties that dictate how a polypeptide folds into a three-dimensional protein.

img.alt: Figure 2. Basic structure of an amino acid

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The monomer that makes up proteins and polypeptides is an amino acid. Each amino acid is made up of the same components – a carboxyl group, an amino group, and an R group, all attached to a central carbon atom as shown in Figure 2. Despite the similarity in their structure, there are twenty different types of amino acids. The differences between amino acids are found in the structure of their R groups. Some R groups consist of a single hydrogen atom while others are made up of carbon chains or rings. These unique structures are also responsible for differences in hydrophobicity, polarity, and other chemical properties between amino acids. It is these properties that dictate how a polypeptide folds into a three-dimensional protein.

img.alt: Figure 2. Basic structure of an amino acid

pageData.text: are the most structurally diverse of the biological molecules, and include fats, oils, waxes, sterols, and phospholipids. Lipids are generally insoluble in water. One function of a lipid is long-term storage of energy; lipids yield twice as many calories per gram as and . are common lipids in plants and animals. The name refers to the structure of three fatty acids joined to an alcohol known as glycerol. The presence of a carboxyl group (-COOH) in an organic compound indicates that the compound is an organic acid. Fatty acids consist of a single carboxyl group attached to long chains (chains of hydrogens and carbons). Naturally occurring fatty acids have even numbers of carbon , form straight chains, and are either saturated or unsaturated. A chain is composed entirely of carbon atoms joined by single . An has one or more double bonds in its carbon chain with two fewer hydrogen atoms per double bond. A hydrogen atom is removed from each carbon involved in the double bond of a fatty acid. The removal of hydrogen is called . A has two or more double bonds in its carbon chain (four, six, etc., and, i.e., fewer hydrogen atoms).

In unsaturated fatty acids, double bonds limit the number of hydrogen atoms attached to the carbon chain. The double bonds also cause ‘kinks’ to form in the long chain of carbon atoms that cannot be straightened. Saturated fatty-acid chains have only carbon-carbon single bonds and are more flexible than chains of unsaturated fatty acids.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>The carbon chains are straight, so the three fatty acids can be packed more tightly. Because of this, triglycerides with saturated fatty acids tend to form solids at much lower temperatures. Saturated fatty acids, such as those in lard, shortening, and butter, are frequently solids at room temperature. The double bonds of unsaturated fatty acids cause the chain to bend and take up more space. Unsaturated fatty acids are usually liquids at room temperature. Triglycerides with saturated fatty acids are usually referred to as fats, whereas unsaturated triglycerides are called oils. Animals usually store lipids as saturated fats, whereas plants tend to store lipids as unsaturated oils. Commonly used oils, such as corn and canola, are triglycerides that contain mostly unsaturated fatty acids.

The family of lipids also includes phospholipids. The structure of a phospholipid consists of a polar phosphate group on one end and a pair of hydrophobic tails. Because of their hydrophobic nature, the tails of the phospholipid tend to form bilayers when immersed in an aqueous environment. These bilayers sequester the hydrophobic ends away from water, whereas the charged phosphate groups are oriented outward toward the water. The majority of the cell membranes are made up of these phospholipid bilayers.Cholesterol, a component of the plasma membrane and a precursor of steroid hormones, is another important . Cholesterol is a steroid that is associated with animal fats, especially saturated fats.Another important type of lipid are the waxes. Waxes are composed of a long-chain fatty acid linked to a long-chain alcohol. They are completely insoluble in water, which makes them excellent at repelling water and preventing water loss. Waxes are largely indigestible by humans and are only produced in the human body in the skin cells in the form of wax esters.

pageData.question: One of the most common lipids in plants and animals is triglyceride. Although triglycerides vary somewhat in their structure, they all have the same basic structure. Which of the following best describes the structure of a triglyceride?

options.text: three fatty acids attached to an alcohol molecule
three glycerol molecules attached to a saturated fatty acid chain
an alcohol molecule attached to a three-carbon fatty acid chain
a fatty acid attached to three alcohol molecules
three fatty acid rings attached to a central glycerol molecule

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: As the name suggests, in a triglyceride three fatty acid chains are attached to one glycerol, which is an alcohol.

pageData.question: The term “hydrogenated oil” is one that you have likely seen on food packaging or heard about in the news. It is a type of fat that food manufacturers developed by adding hydrogen atoms to unsaturated fat. Based on what you know about lipids, which of the following best describes a hydrogenated oil?

options.text: A solid fat that resembles naturally occurring saturated fat.
A liquid fat that is soluble in water.
A liquid fat that is carbonated with hydrogen gas.
A solid fat with a high melting point.
A fat that is gaseous at room temperature.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Hydrogenated oils are unsaturated fats that have been modified by the addition of hydrogen atoms, which removes the double bonds in the fatty acid chains and changes them from unsaturated to saturated fatty acids. Hydrogenated oils are made from liquid vegetable oils but have a semi-solid or solid consistency.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are many different types of triglycerides found in plants and animals. Based on the structure of the fatty acid chains in a triglyceride, the molecule will perform different functions and have different chemical properties. However, all triglycerides have the same basic structure. Glycerol, a type of alcohol (shown here in black), is bonded to three fatty acid chains. These chains can be saturated or unsaturated, but this basic structure remains the same. Saturated fatty acids are hydrocarbon chains with no double bonds; they are “saturated” with hydrogen atoms. Unsaturated fatty acids are hydrocarbon chains with one more double bonds. The straight chain structure of saturated fatty acids means saturated fat molecules stack on each other easily, forming solids at room temperature. In contrast, unsaturated fatty acids are not straight chains and are liquid at room temperature.

img.alt: The chemical structure of a triglyceride molecule.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are many different types of triglycerides found in plants and animals. Based on the structure of the fatty acid chains in a triglyceride, the molecule will perform different functions and have different chemical properties. However, all triglycerides have the same basic structure. Glycerol, a type of alcohol (shown here in black), is bonded to three fatty acid chains. These chains can be saturated or unsaturated, but this basic structure remains the same. Saturated fatty acids are hydrocarbon chains with no double bonds; they are “saturated” with hydrogen atoms. Unsaturated fatty acids are hydrocarbon chains with one more double bonds. The straight chain structure of saturated fatty acids means saturated fat molecules stack on each other easily, forming solids at room temperature. In contrast, unsaturated fatty acids are not straight chains and are liquid at room temperature.

img.alt: The chemical structure of a triglyceride molecule.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Nucleic acids</button> are responsible for transmitting genetic information. The <button class='glossary-text'>monomers</button> that form the links of a nucleic-acid chain are called <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotides</button>. Each nucleotide has three parts: a pentose (five-carbon) sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base. The nucleotides are connected to each other by phosphate-to-sugar <button class='glossary-text'>covalent bonds</button>, which form the backbone of the chain. The nitrogenous bases of each nucleotide are connected at right angles to the sugar molecule. These repeating nucleotides form a nucleic acid, such as the partial DNA molecule depicted in Figure 4.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak><button class='glossary-text'>Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)</button>, which is named for its five-carbon sugar, deoxyribose, is one type of nucleic acid. Two DNA strands form a double helix, which can be compared to a twisted ladder. Figure 4 shows part of just one DNA strand. The rungs of the ladder are formed by complementary pairing of the nitrogenous bases in each strand. DNA contains four bases. The purines, adenine (A) and guanine (G), have two nitrogen-containing rings each, and the pyrimidines, cytosine (C) and thymine (T) have one ring each.

<button class='glossary-text'>Hydrogen bonds</button>, which are weak bonds between hydrogen and nitrogen or oxygen hold the two strands together. Adenine and thymine form two hydrogen bonds. Guanine and cytosine form three hydrogen bonds. Therefore, adenine and thymine always pair with each other, as do guanine and cytosine. The diameter of the helix (20 angstroms) is too small to accommodate a purine-purine dimer and too large for a pyrimidine-pyrimidine dimer.

pageData.desc: Figure 4. Part of a single strand of DNA
pageData.altText: Figure 4. Part of a single strand of DNA

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Ribonucleic acid (RNA)</button> is single-stranded and is involved in <button class='glossary-text'>protein</button> synthesis. The sugar of RNA is a five-carbon pentose sugar called ribose. In RNA, the nitrogenous base thymine is replaced by uracil.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak><button class='glossary-text'>Adenosine triphosphate (ATP)</button> is a nucleotide composed of adenine, a pentose sugar (ribose or deoxyribose), and three phosphates. This is an unstable molecule. Disruption of the bond connecting the second and third phosphates releases a large amount of energy, with the formation of adenosine diphosphate (ADP). ADP is much more stable than ATP. The energy released during this reaction drives most cellular processes that require energy, including active transport, motility, and cell division. ATP is formed from ADP during cellular respiration.

pageData.question: The nucleic acid deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) consists of two strands of nucleotides arranged as a twisted ladder, also called a double helix. Which of the following best describes the chemical bonds that hold a DNA molecule together?

options.text: Phosphate-to-sugar covalent bonds form each strand; hydrogen bonds form the ladder.
Hydrogen bonds form each strand; ionic bonds form the ladder.
Nitrogenous base-to-sugar covalent bonds form each strand; hydrogen bonds form the ladder.
Phosphate-to-sugar covalent bonds form each strand; glycosidic bonds form the ladder.
Peptide bonds form each strand; covalent double bonds form the ladder.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The nucleotides in each strand are bonded to one another by phosphate-to-sugar covalent bonds. The nucleotides that complement each other across the molecule to form the rungs of the twisted ladder are attracted to each other by hydrogen bonds.

pageData.question: The covalent bond that connects two nucleotides together in a chain is between what components of the adjacent nucleotides?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The nucleotides in a nucleic acid strand are bonded to one another by phosphate-to-sugar covalent bonds.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Nucleic acids, such as deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA), are made up of chains of monomers called nucleotides. Each nucleotide consists of three components – a five-carbon sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base. DNA and RNA differ from one another in part because of the structure of the sugars and nitrogenous bases found in each molecule. To form the nucleotide chains, the phosphate group of one monomer is covalently bonded to the sugar of another monomer. RNA molecules consist of only one such nucleotide chain, or strand. DNA molecules, however, consist of two strands. These strands are arranged parallel to one another with the nitrogenous bases facing inward, forming hydrogen bonds across the molecule that roughly resemble rungs on a ladder.

img.alt: The chemical structure of a section of a DNA molecule.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Nucleic acids, such as deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA), are made up of chains of monomers called nucleotides. Each nucleotide consists of three components – a five-carbon sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base. DNA and RNA differ from one another in part because of the structure of the sugars and nitrogenous bases found in each molecule. To form the nucleotide chains, the phosphate group of one monomer is covalently bonded to the sugar of another monomer. RNA molecules consist of only one such nucleotide chain, or strand. DNA molecules, however, consist of two strands. These strands are arranged parallel to one another with the nitrogenous bases facing inward, forming hydrogen bonds across the molecule that roughly resemble rungs on a ladder.

img.alt: The chemical structure of a section of a DNA molecule.

pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation.
You will start by organizing the pieces of molecular model kit.
In Activity 1, you will build an open-chain glucose model. Then, transform the glucose model into cyclic glucose. Are 4 cyclic glucose models built? If so, proceed. If not, go back one step.  Then build a branched polysaccharide model. Next, disassemble the models.
In Activity 2, you will build 4 different amino acid models. Then, build a polypeptide model. Next disassemble the model.

In Activity 3, you will build a stearic acid model. Then you will transform this lipid model into an oleic acid model. Next, transform this lipid model into a linolenic acid model. Then, disassemble the model.  Then, build a triglyceride model. Finish the activity by disassembling the model.
In Activity 4, you will build two complementary nucleotide models. Then, arrange the models into a DNA model. Next transform the DNA model into an RNA model. Then, you will transform the nucleotide model into an ATP model. Finally, disassemble the models.

pageData.text: Select each tab to continue

content.subTitle: A molecular model set consisting of:

content.label: 36 Carbon atoms (4 projections, black)
content.altText: Plastic model of carbon atom in black

content.label: 72 Hydrogen atoms (1 projection, white)
content.altText: Plastic model of hydrogen atom in white

content.label: 26 Oxygen atoms (2 projections, red)
content.altText: Plastic model of oxygen atom in red

content.label: 10 Nitrogen atoms (3 projections, blue)
content.altText: Model of nitrogen atom in blue

content.label: 6 Phosphorous atoms (5 projections, purple)
content.altText: Plastic model of phosphorous atom in purple

content.label: 112 Covalent bonds (white tubing)
content.altText: Model of covalent bond; small white tube

content.text:
• Permanent marker
  • Masking or labeling tape
  • Digital camera or smart phone

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Biological Macromolecules for Anatomy and Physiology investigation (item number 580120) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
This kit contains small parts, which may be choking hazards. The pieces of the molecular model kit should be kept out of the reach of children.
Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following sets of functional groups best describes the general structure of all amino acids?
Which of the following molecules catalyzes chemical reactions in living things?
Which of the following molecules would be considered a polysaccharide?
Which of the following is NOT a characteristic that distinguishes ribonucleic acid (RNA) from deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)?

options.text: An RNA strand is held together by covalent double bonds.
The nucleotide uracil is present in RNA.
RNA molecules are directly involved in protein synthesis.
An RNA nucleotide contains a five-carbon ribose sugar.

assestmentData.question: The breakdown of a polysaccharide into its monosaccharide monomers would produce which of the following byproducts?
Which of the following best describes the structural difference between saturated fat and unsaturated fat?

options.text: Saturated fats have fatty acid chains without double bonds.
Saturated fats have fatty acid chains with triple bonds.
Saturated fats have more than three fatty acid chains.
Saturated fats have less than three fatty acid chains.
Saturated fats have more than one glycerol.

assestmentData.question: Organic molecules are held together primarily by covalent bonds. Which of the following best describes a covalent bond?

options.text: A nitrogen atom sees electrons more often than an attached hydrogen does.
A hydrogen atom donates an electron to a chlorine atom.
A carbon atom shares electrons equally with hydrogen atoms.
An iodine atom accepts an electron from a potassium atom.
An oxygen atom has a weak attraction to a nearby hydrogen atom.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a safety concern in this laboratory investigation?

options.text: The kit contains small parts that are a choking hazard for pets and children.
Glass could break; broken glass should not be picked up with your hands.
Some chemicals give off fumes; use chemicals in a well-ventilated room.
Household bleach is a corrosive chemical.
There are no safety concerns in this investigation.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following characteristics of an organic molecule is most responsible for its chemical reactivity?

options.text: the number of monomers in a polymer
the location of any double and triple bonds

assestmentData.question: Adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the molecule which provides the energy to drive certain cellular processes, is categorized as what type of macromolecule?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read the instructions for each activity carefully before you start.
Obtain all materials.
Open both molecular model kits and remove all components.
Sort the white hydrogen <button class='glossary-text'>atoms</button>, the black carbon atoms, and the red oxygen atoms into separate compartments of one Y-plate Petri dish.
Sort the blue nitrogen atoms and the purple phosphate atoms into separate compartments of the second Y-plate Petri dish.

typeAfter.text: Note: Two-dimensional structural formulas are presented in the following instructions for each activity. A three-dimensional molecular model may look different from the corresponding structural formula. A structural formula shows how atoms are bonded together in two dimensions but does not exactly replicate the complete model.

pageData.text: Place the white pieces of tubing, which represent <button class='glossary-text'>covalent bonds</button>, into the lids of the Petri dishes.

In Activity 1, you will model <button class='glossary-text'>carbohydrates</button>. You will start creating an open chain glucose molecule, which you will transform into a cyclical glucose molecule. After creating four total cyclic glucose molecules, you will create several <button class='glossary-text'>polysaccharide</button> molecules, as well as model the removal of glucose by <button class='glossary-text'>hydrolysis</button>.

typeBefore.title: Glucose<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>Materials:
typeBefore.text:
6 Carbon
6 Oxygen atoms
12 Hydrogen atoms
24

pageData.text: Connect a carbon atom to a covalent bond.

typeAfter.desc: Figure 5. First carbon atom labeled with masking tape with the number 1 written on it.
typeAfter.altText: Figure 5. First carbon atom labeled with masking tape with the number 1 written on it.

pageData.text: Wrap a piece of labeling tape around the covalent bond near the carbon atom (carbon #1, “C1”), and label it “1” with a permanent marker as shown in Figure 5.

typeAfter.desc: Figure 6. First and second carbon atoms labeled 1 and 2 with the numbers written on masking tape.
typeAfter.altText: Figure 6. First and second carbon atoms labeled 1 and 2 with the numbers written on masking tape.

pageData.text: Add a carbon atom (carbon #2, “C2”) to the end of the labeled covalent bond. Add a covalent bond to C2, and label it “2” near the carbon atom as shown in Figure 6.
Repeat Step 3 for four additional carbon atoms (C3–C6). When the model is released, it should curve back around on itself, forming a ring.
Attach an oxygen atom to C1 using two bonds (a double bond).
Form five –OH groups by attaching one hydrogen atom to each of the five remaining oxygen atoms.
To attach the five –OH groups to the carbon chain in the positions indicated in Figure 7, you will need to stretch out the carbon chain.
Attach hydrogen atoms to the empty spaces in the carbon chain as shown in Figure 7.
This is a model of an open-chain glucose molecule. Seven hydrogens were added to complete the glucose molecule.
Label the model and take a photograph for future reference. The chemical formula for glucose is C<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>12</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>.

typeAfter.desc: Figure 8. Twisted carbon chain of glucose
typeAfter.altText: Figure 8. Twisted carbon chain of glucose

pageData.text: To demonstrate the cyclic structure of glucose, carefully twist the carbon chain to bring C1 and C5 together (see Figure 8).
Detach one bond from the oxygen atom connected to C1, but leave the bond attached to the carbon atom. This represents breaking the carbon-oxygen double bond but keeping the single bond.
Remove the hydrogen from the –OH group of C5, and attach it to the oxygen attached to C1, forming a new OH group (see Figure 9).

Attach the oxygen of C5 to C1 to complete the ring as shown in Figure 9. C1 now has two carbon-oxygen single bonds. The orientation of the hydrogen and hydroxyl group is important. In the configuration below, the glucose is known as α-D-glucose. If the hydrogen and hydroxyl group on C1 are reversed, the molecule becomes β-D-glucose. Likewise, if the hydrogen and hydroxyl group are reversed on C4, the molecule becomes GA lactose, a sugar found in milk. Molecules that have the same chemical formula but different structures and properties are called isomers; in this case, glucose and lactose are stereoisomers because the atoms are connected in the same order. Fructose, a sugar found in fruit, also has the chemical formula C<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>12</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>; but, in this case, the ring is a pentagon rather than a hexagon as shown in Figure 10. These basic <button class='glossary-text'>monosaccharide</button> units can be combined in pairs to form dimers, or in larger groupings to form a <button class='glossary-text'>polysaccharide</button>, or complex <button class='glossary-text'>carbohydrate</button>. Label the model and take a photograph for future reference.
Create three more cyclic glucose molecules as shown in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 9</button>.

typeAfter.desc: Figure 11. Two cyclic glucose molecules positioned for dehydration synthesis
typeAfter.altText: Figure 11. Two cyclic glucose molecules positioned for dehydration synthesis

pageData.text: Lay two glucose molecules side by side with the C1 of one lying next to the C4 of the next (see Figure 11).

Remove the hydroxyl group from the C1 on the left, but leave a covalent bond attached. Remove the hydrogen from the hydroxyl group on the C4 on the molecule on the right. Connect the two molecules. This forms an α-1,4-<button class='glossary-text'>glycosidic bond</button> (1 and 4 refer to the numbers of the carbon atoms involved in the bond). This is the disaccharide maltose (see Figure 12). After combining the two molecules, a hydroxide ion (-OH) and a hydrogen ion remain. Join these two groups together to form a water molecule. This reaction is called dehydration synthesis because a water molecule is removed from the reactants. Maltose has the chemical formula C<sub class=bodySubscript>12</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>22</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>11</sub>, which is shared by sucrose (table sugar); i.e., maltose and sucrose are isomers.

typeBefore.text: The right side of the molecule is the reducing end, while the left side is the non-reducing end. Reducing and nonreducing refer to the ability of the glucose ring on that end of the molecule to open into a chain with an aldehyde group. The aldehyde group can be oxidized.

pageData.text: Place another glucose molecule on the right side of the maltose molecule. Repeat the dehydration synthesis. There are now three glucose molecules connected in a chain. This is the beginning of an amylose molecule. A full-length amylose <button class='glossary-text'>polymer</button> can contain between 250 and 4000 individual glucose units. Amylose is one of the two main components of starch and makes up approximately 25% of the mass of a starch molecule.
Place the last glucose molecule above the center glucose ring of the chain.

Remove the hydroxyl group from the C1 on the left, but leave a covalent bond attached. Remove the hydrogen from the hydroxyl group on the C6 on the right-hand molecule. Connect the two molecules. This forms an α-1,6-glycosidic bond. This branched molecule can be the beginning of either an amylopectin molecule (the other component of starch) or a glycogen molecule.

To simulate the removal of glucose from a polysaccharide by <button class='glossary-text'>hydrolysis</button> (reaction with water), disconnect the C1 of the left-hand carbon ring from the oxygen that links it to the C4 of the center ring, leaving the covalent bond on the C1 atom. Remove a hydroxyl group from the water molecules generated in the dehydration reaction. Attach the hydroxide ion to the C1 atom of the detached glucose molecule. Attach the remaining hydrogen ion to the oxygen attached to the C4 atom of the other ring. Label the model and take a photograph for future reference.
In Activity 2, you will model amino acids and polypeptides. You will start by creating four different amino acid molecules, then combining three amino acids via peptide bonds to create a polypeptide.
Attach three hydrogen <button class='glossary-text'>atoms</button> to a nitrogen atom. This is a model of an ammonia molecule (NH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>).
Remove one hydrogen atom. The remaining group of atoms, –NH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>, is the amino group.
Use two covalent bonds to create a double bond between an oxygen atom and a carbon atom.
Attach an –OH group to the carbon atom. This is the carboxyl group.
Attach the carboxyl (–COOH) and amino (–NH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>) groups and one hydrogen atom to a carbon atom as shown in Figure 13.
Attach a hydrogen atom in place of the “R” that is shown in Figure 13. This is glycine, the simplest amino acid. Compare the model to the structure shown in Figure 13.

typeAfter.title: Amino Acids Alanine, Valine, and Glutamine

pageData.text: Label the model and take a photograph for future reference.

typeAfter.desc: Figure 14. Alanine, valine, and glutamine molecules
typeAfter.altText: Figure 14. Alanine, valine, and glutamine molecules

pageData.text: Figure 14 shows three more amino acids. Notice that the structures are similar to the basic structure of an amino acid shown in Figure 13. Build a molecular model of each of these amino acids.
Align two amino acid molecules as shown in Figure 15.

typeBefore.desc: Figure 15. Two amino acid molecules positioned for dehydration synthesis
typeBefore.altText: Figure 15. Two amino acid molecules positioned for dehydration synthesis

pageData.text: Bring together the carboxyl end of one amino acid and the amino end of another. Join the two ends by removing a molecule of water (–OH from the carboxyl group and –H from the amino group) and attaching carbon to nitrogen. The resulting molecule is a dipeptide, and the bond linking the two peptides is a peptide bond.

typeAfter.text: Note: Long polypeptide strands usually contain 50+ amino acids and can be twisted and folded to form a .

pageData.text: Repeat Step 10 to attach a third amino acid to the dipeptide. This molecule is a polypeptide.
Label the molecule “polypeptide” and take a photograph for future reference.
Disassemble the molecular model and return the pieces to the appropriate compartments of the Y-plate Petri dishes.

In Activity 3, you will model <button class='glossary-text'>lipids</button>. You will start by creating a stearic acid molecule, which you will transform into an oleic acid molecule, and then a linolenic acid molecule. You will then build three butyric acid molecules and a glycerol molecule, which you will combine to create a <button class='glossary-text'>triglyceride</button> molecule.
Attach two <button class='glossary-text'>covalent bonds</button> to an oxygen <button class='glossary-text'>atom</button>.
Connect both covalent bonds to a single carbon atom. This is a carbon-oxygen double bond.
Attach another covalent bond to the carbon atom. Wrap a piece of labeling tape around the covalent bond near the carbon atom (C1), and label it “1” with a permanent marker.
Connect two covalent bonds to an oxygen atom. Attach a hydrogen atom to one of the covalent bonds. This is a hydroxyl (–OH) group.
Attach the hydroxyl (–OH) group to C1 to form a carboxyl (–COOH) group.
Attach a chain of 17 carbon atoms and 17 covalent bonds to the carboxyl group. Label these carbon atoms 2–17 on the covalent bond near each carbon atom.

Add a covalent bond and hydrogen atom to each available space on the carbon chain. C2 through C16 will each be attached to two hydrogen atoms. C17 will be attached to three hydrogen atoms. This molecule is stearic acid.
Label the model “stearic acid” and take a photograph for future reference.
Remove one hydrogen atom from C9 of the stearic acid model. Remove one hydrogen atom and the covalent bond from C10.
Use the remaining covalent bond on C9 to attach C10 with a double bond. This molecule is oleic acid.
Label the model “oleic acid” and take a photograph for future reference.

Starting with the model of oleic acid, remove one hydrogen atom from C12 and one hydrogen atom and the covalent bond from C13. Connect these carbon atoms with a double bond. This will be the second carbon-carbon double bond in this molecule.

Repeat the preceding step with C15 and C16 to create a third carbon-carbon double bond. This molecule is linolenic acid, the major component of linseed oil. Label the model and take a photograph for future reference.
Remove the labeling tape from the covalent bonds.
Disassemble the molecular models and return the pieces to the appropriate compartments of the Y-plate Petri dish.
Build a four-carbon chain.
Add a carbon-oxygen double bond at C1.
Add an –OH group to C1 to create a carboxyl (-COOH) group.
Add a hydrogen to each free space on the other three carbons. This molecule is butyric acid (see Figure 16).
Build two more butyric acid molecules.
Examine the structural formula for glycerol shown in Figure 17. Build a model of the glycerol molecule.
The three molecules of butyric acid will be attached to the glycerol molecule.

First, remove a hydroxyl group from each butyric acid and a hydrogen atom from each of the hydroxyl groups on the glycerol. These atoms can be combined to form three molecules of water (one hydrogen atom attached to each hydroxyl group).
Attach the oxygen on the glycerol to the carbon atom on the butyric acid molecule. C1 on the butyric acid has a carbon-oxygen double bond and a carbon-oxygen single bond that attaches to glycerol.
Repeat for the other two molecules of butyric acid.

This molecule is glycerol tributyrate, a simple <button class='glossary-text'>triglyceride</button>. Notice that each carboxyl group connects to a hydroxyl group in glycerol as indicated in Figure 18.
Label the model and take a photograph for future reference.
Disassemble the molecular model and return the pieces to the appropriate compartments of the Y-plate petri dish.

In Activity 4, you will model <button class='glossary-text'>nucleic acids</button>. You will create a thymine <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotide</button> and an adenine nucleotide, which you will align to identify the <button class='glossary-text'>hydrogen bonds</button> in a DNA helix. You will then modify the DNA nucleotides into RNA nucleotides. You will conclude the activity by taking the RNA adenine molecule and transforming it into <button class='glossary-text'>adenosine triphosphate (ATP)</button>.

Use two <button class='glossary-text'>covalent bonds</button> to form a double bond between an oxygen and a purple phosphorous <button class='glossary-text'>atom</button>. Attach three additional oxygen molecules to the phosphorous with single covalent bonds. This is a model of a phosphate group (PO4<sup class=bodySupscript>-3</sup>) (Figure 19, green).

Refer to Figure 19 to build the pentose sugar, deoxyribose, of one DNA <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotide</button>. Label carbons C1–C5 as shown. Note that C1 is connected to the right of the oxygen atom at the tip of the ring. Leave one peg open on C1 to attach to the nitrogenous base.
Build the nitrogenous base thymine by attaching an oxygen atom to a carbon atom with a double bond. Refer to Figure 20 to build this base.
Attach the thymine ring to C1 of the pentose molecule built in Step 2.
Repeat Steps 1 and 2 to form a second pentose sugar.
Build the nitrogenous base adenine by attaching a nitrogen atom to a carbon atom with a double bond. Refer to Figure 21 to build this nitrogenous base.

typeAfter.desc: Figure 22. Hydrogen bonding joins adenine and thymine in the DNA molecule
typeAfter.altText: Figure 22. Hydrogen bonding joins adenine and thymine in the DNA molecule

pageData.text: To simulate how adenine and thymine form <button class='glossary-text'>hydrogen bonds</button> in the DNA helix, arrange adenine and thymine as shown in Figure 22.
Label the model “DNA” and take a photograph for future reference.
To modify the model of DNA to represent RNA, replace deoxyribose on adenine with ribose. Replace the hydrogen on C2 of ribose with a hydroxyl (–OH). Refer to Figure 23.
Replace deoxyribose on thymine with ribose by replacing hydrogen on C2 of each pentose sugar with a hydroxyl group.
RNA does not contain thymine. Convert thymine to the pyrimidine uracil by removing the methyl (–CH3) group from thymine. Replace the methyl group with a hydrogen atom. See Figure 24.
Label the RNA nucleotides and take a photograph for future reference.

Save the model of adenine to build an ATP molecule in the next section of this activity. Disassemble the uracil model and return the pieces to the appropriate compartments of the Y-plate Petri dishes.
Use two covalent bonds to create a double bond between the red oxygen atom and a purple phosphorous atom.
Attach three covalent bonds to the remaining projections on the phosphorous atom.
Attach oxygen atoms to two of the covalent bonds to form a phosphate.
Attach a purple phosphorus atom to the fourth covalent bond.
Attach one oxygen atom to the second phosphorus atom with an oxygen-phosphorus double bond. Attach the second oxygen atom to the phosphorus atom with an oxygen-phosphorus single bond.
Assemble an ATP molecule from the adenosine RNA nucleotide and the double phosphate as shown in Figure 25.
Label the molecule “ATP” and take a photograph for future reference.
Remove the labeling tape from the covalent bonds.
Disassemble the molecular model and return all the pieces to the appropriate compartments of the Y-plate Petri dishes.

pageData.title: Disposal and Cleanup
text: Disassemble all models and return the pieces to the bag.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation.
You will start by organizing the pieces of molecular model kit.
In Activity 1, you will build an open-chain glucose model. Then, transform the glucose model into cyclic glucose. Are 4 cyclic glucose models built? If so, proceed. If not, go back one step.  Then build a branched polysaccharide model. Next, disassemble the models.
In Activity 2, you will build 4 different amino acid models. Then, build a polypeptide model. Next disassemble the model.

In Activity 3, you will build a stearic acid model. Then you will transform this lipid model into an oleic acid model. Next, transform this lipid model into a linolenic acid model. Then, disassemble the model.  Then, build a triglyceride model. Finish the activity by disassembling the model.
In Activity 4, you will build two complementary nucleotide models. Then, arrange the models into a DNA model. Next transform the DNA model into an RNA model. Then, you will transform the nucleotide model into an ATP model. Finally, disassemble the models.

data.title: Adenosine triphosphate (ATP)
data.content: Is the main energy currency of the cell

data.title: Atom
data.content: The fundamental building blocks of matter, making up the 118 currently known elements, consist of three major particles: protons, neutrons, and electrons

data.title: Bonding orbital
data.content: The region between the two atoms where the shared electrons are most likely to be found

data.title: Carbohydrate
data.content: A chemical compound that has an empirical formula (simplest whole-number ratio of atoms) of CH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O, which indicates a ratio of 1:2:1 for carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen, respectively

data.title: Chemical bond
data.content: Attraction holding atoms together in a molecule

data.title: Covalent bond
data.content: A chemical bond in which there is a  sharing of an electron pair between two atoms

data.title: Dehydrogenation
data.content: Removal of hydrogen

data.title: Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)
data.content: Five-carbon sugar, deoxyribose, contains four bases. The purines, adenine (A) and guanine (G), have two nitrogen-containing rings each, and the pyrimi-dines, cytosine (C) and thymine (T) have one ring each

data.title: Electron
data.content: Subatomic particle occurring in all atomic nuclei, with a negative electric charge

data.title: Electronegativity
data.content: The tendency of an atom to attract a bonding pair of electrons

data.title: Essential amino acid
data.content: Nine amino acids that cannot be synthesized by the human body, and must be supplied in a diet

data.title: Glycosidic bond
data.content: Covalent bond that joins a carbohydrate (sugar) molecule to another group

data.title: Hydrocarbon
data.content: Organic chemical compound that consists of only of the elements carbon (C) and hydrogen (H)

data.title: Hydrogen bond
data.content: A bond formed between an electropositive atom, usually hydrogen, and a strongly electronegative atom, such as oxygen or nitrogen

data.title: Hydrolysis
data.content: Breakdown of a compound usually due to reaction with water

data.title: Ionic bond
data.content: A chemical bond formed when one atom gives up one or more electrons to another atom

data.title: Lipid
data.content: Most structurally diverse of the biological molecules, and include fats, oils, waxes, sterols, and phospholipids

data.title: Monomer
data.content: Individual unit of polymers

data.title: Monosaccharide
data.content: Monomers of carbohydrates, the least complex of the carbohydrate molecules and are often called “simple sugars.”

data.title: Neutron
data.content: Subatomic particle occurring in all atomic nuclei, except H, same mass as a proton but without an electric charge

data.title: Nonessential amino acid
data.content: Can be synthesized within the body, required for normal health and growth

data.title: Nucleic acid
data.content: Are composed of monomers called nucleotides, Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA)

data.title: Nucleotide
data.content: Has three parts: a pentose (five-carbon) sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base

data.title: Organic chemistry
data.content: The study of carbon and especially carbon compounds which are found in living thing

data.title: Peptide bond
data.content: A chemical bond formed between two molecules when the carboxyl group of one molecule reacts with the amino group of the other molecule

data.title: Polymer
data.content: A large number of similar units bonded together,

data.title: Polymerized
data.content: A process of reacting monomer molecules together in a chemical reaction to form polymer chains

data.title: Polysaccharide
data.content: The most complex carbohydrates, and they contain several mono-saccharides linked in various configurations

data.title: Polyunsaturated fatty acid
data.content: Has two or more double bonds in its carbon chain (four, six, etc., and, i.e., fewer hydrogen atoms)

data.title: Primary structure
data.content: A biological molecule in which there is a precise sequence or order of monomeric units

data.title: Protein
data.content: Complex organic compounds composed of monomers called amino acids

data.title: Proton
data.content: Subatomic particle occurring in all atomic nuclei, with a positive electric charge

data.title: Quaternary structure
data.content: The association of several protein chains or subunits into a closely packed arrangement

data.title: Ribonucleic acid (RNA)
data.content: Single-stranded, involved in protein synthesis. The sugar of RNA is a five-carbon pentose sugar called ribose

data.title: Saturated fatty acid
data.content: Composed entirely of carbon atoms joined by single covalent bonds

data.title: Secondary structure
data.content: A biological molecule characterized by the local folding within the biopolymer as a result of hydrogen bonding

data.title: Tertiary structure
data.content: Folding of the secondary structure, molecule becomes functional

data.title: Triglyceride
data.content: Contain three fatty acid chains bonded to a glycerol molecule (a sugar alcohol)

data.title: Unsaturated fatty acid
data.content: Has one or more double bonds in its carbon chain with two fewer hydrogen atoms per double bond
